tasks.question: Who were the legendary founders of Rome?
tasks.hint: Think of twin brothers raised by a wolf.
tasks.introText: Rome's foundation is steeped in myth and legend.
tasks.postSolutionText: Romulus and Remus were twin brothers said to be raised by a she-wolf. Romulus eventually founded Rome, naming it after himself.

tasks.question: Match the Roman gods with their Greek counterparts:
tasks.hint: Many Roman gods have similar roles to Greek gods.
tasks.introText: Roman mythology was heavily influenced by Greek mythology.
tasks.postSolutionText: Romans adopted many Greek gods, often giving them new names but similar attributes and stories.

tasks.question: Rome was founded in the year ___ BCE on the banks of the ___ River.
tasks.hint: The traditional founding date is in the 8th century BCE.
tasks.introText: The founding of Rome has a traditional date accepted by ancient Romans.
tasks.postSolutionText: 753 BCE is the traditional founding date of Rome, located on the banks of the Tiber River.

tasks.question: The early Roman Kingdom was ruled by elected consuls.
tasks.hint: Consider the term 'kingdom' carefully.
tasks.introText: Rome's government evolved over time, starting with a different system.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. The early Roman Kingdom was ruled by kings, not consuls. Consuls came later with the Roman Republic.

tasks.question: What was the social class of the common people in ancient Rome?
tasks.hint: This class made up the majority of Roman citizens.
tasks.introText: Roman society was divided into distinct social classes.
tasks.postSolutionText: Plebeians were the common people of Rome, distinct from the patrician elite.

tasks.question: In what year was the Roman Republic established?
tasks.hint: It was established shortly after the overthrow of the last king.
tasks.introText: The Roman Republic replaced the Roman Kingdom.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Roman Republic was established in 509 BCE after the overthrow of Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, the last Roman king.

tasks.question: Match the Roman offices with their responsibilities:

possibleAnswers.Responsibility: Maintain the census and oversee public morality
Oversee financial affairs and assist governors

tasks.hint: Each office had specific roles in the Roman government.
tasks.introText: The Roman Republic had various political offices with distinct responsibilities.
tasks.postSolutionText: These offices formed the core of the Roman Republican government, each with crucial roles in maintaining the state.

tasks.question: The highest legislative assembly in the Roman Republic was called the ___ ___.
tasks.hint: This assembly was organized on the basis of military units.
tasks.introText: Rome had several assemblies, each with different powers and compositions.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Centuriate Assembly was the highest-ranking assembly, organized on the basis of military units called centuries.

tasks.question: The Roman Senate had the power to pass laws on its own.
tasks.hint: Consider the role of assemblies in law-making.
tasks.introText: The Roman Senate was a powerful body, but had specific limitations.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. While influential, the Senate could not pass laws on its own. Laws had to be approved by one of the assemblies.

tasks.question: What was the name of the law code that formed the foundation of Roman civil law?
tasks.hint: This code was created in the early Republic and displayed publicly in the Forum.
tasks.introText: Early Roman law was codified to protect plebeian rights.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Twelve Tables, created around 450 BCE, were the foundation of Roman civil law and were displayed publicly for all citizens to read.

tasks.question: What was the basic unit of Roman society?
tasks.hint: This unit was headed by the paterfamilias.
tasks.introText: Roman society was built on fundamental social structures.
tasks.postSolutionText: The family, or 'familia', was the basic unit of Roman society, headed by the paterfamilias who held significant power over family members.

tasks.question: Match the Roman clothing items with their descriptions:

possibleAnswers.Description: Long, draped garment worn by male citizens
Long, pleated dress worn by married women
Basic undergarment worn by both sexes
Shawl or cloak worn by women

tasks.hint: Each item had a specific role in Roman fashion.
tasks.introText: Roman clothing was diverse and often indicated social status.
tasks.postSolutionText: Roman clothing was not just for practicality but also signified social status, gender, and occasion.

tasks.question: The most popular form of entertainment in Rome was the ___ held in the ___.
tasks.hint: These violent spectacles involved trained fighters.
tasks.introText: Romans enjoyed various forms of public entertainment.
tasks.postSolutionText: Gladiatorial games held in the Colosseum were the most popular entertainment, showcasing combat between gladiators or against wild animals.

tasks.question: Latin was the only language spoken throughout the Roman Empire.
tasks.hint: Consider the diversity of the empire and the influence of Greek culture.
tasks.introText: The Roman Empire encompassed many cultures and languages.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. While Latin was the official language, Greek was widely spoken in the eastern provinces, and local languages persisted in many areas.

tasks.question: What was the Roman system of patronage called?
tasks.hint: This system involved a reciprocal relationship between patrons and clients.
tasks.introText: Social relationships in Rome often involved complex systems of obligation and favor.
tasks.postSolutionText: The clientela system was a fundamental part of Roman society, where powerful patrons provided protection and favors to clients in exchange for political support.

tasks.question: What was the highest judicial official in the Roman Republic?
tasks.hint: This official was responsible for the administration of justice.
tasks.introText: The Roman legal system had various officials with specific roles.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Praetor was the highest judicial official, responsible for the administration of justice and the development of Roman law.

tasks.question: Match the legal concepts with their descriptions:

possibleAnswers.Description: Civil law applicable to Roman citizens
Law of nations, applicable to non-citizens
Natural law, based on reason and equity

tasks.hint: These concepts formed the basis of Roman legal thinking.
tasks.introText: Roman law was divided into several branches or concepts.
tasks.postSolutionText: These different branches of law show the complexity and sophistication of the Roman legal system, which greatly influenced modern Western law.

tasks.question: The ___ ___ was a Roman citizen's right to appeal to the people's assembly against a magistrate's decision.
tasks.hint: This right was a fundamental protection against arbitrary punishment.
tasks.introText: Roman citizens had certain legal rights and protections.
tasks.postSolutionText: Provocatio ad populum was an important right that allowed citizens to appeal to the people's assembly, serving as a check on magistrates' power.

tasks.question: The concept of 'innocent until proven guilty' originated in Roman law.
tasks.hint: Consider the differences between ancient and modern legal principles.
tasks.introText: Many modern legal principles have roots in ancient systems, but not all.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. While Roman law was advanced for its time, 'innocent until proven guilty' is a more modern legal principle. Roman trials often placed the burden of proof on the accused.

tasks.question: What was the name of the supreme executive magistrate in the Roman Republic?
tasks.hint: This office was held by two individuals simultaneously for a one-year term.
tasks.introText: The Roman Republic had various important magistracies.
tasks.postSolutionText: Consuls were the highest-ranking magistrates in the Roman Republic. Two were elected each year to share power and prevent any individual from becoming too powerful.

tasks.question: Who was the chief deity of the Roman pantheon?
tasks.hint: This god was equivalent to the Greek Zeus.
tasks.introText: The Roman pantheon included many gods and goddesses.
tasks.postSolutionText: Jupiter was the king of the gods in Roman religion, associated with the sky, thunder, and lightning. He was equivalent to the Greek Zeus.

tasks.question: Match the Roman gods with their domains:
tasks.hint: Each god had specific areas of influence in Roman life.
tasks.introText: Roman gods were associated with various aspects of life and nature.
tasks.postSolutionText: Roman gods had specific domains that reflected important aspects of Roman life and the natural world.

tasks.question: The ___ were priestesses who maintained the sacred fire of ___.
tasks.hint: These priestesses took a vow of chastity and served for 30 years.
tasks.introText: Some Roman religious offices had very specific and important duties.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Vestal Virgins were priestesses of Vesta, goddess of the hearth. They maintained the sacred fire in the Temple of Vesta, which was never allowed to go out.

tasks.question: The Roman state religion was monotheistic.
tasks.hint: Consider the number of gods in the Roman pantheon.
tasks.introText: Religious beliefs varied across the long history of Rome.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. Roman state religion was polytheistic, worshipping many gods and goddesses. Monotheism became significant later with the rise of Christianity.

tasks.question: What was the practice of interpreting the will of the gods by studying the flight of birds?
tasks.hint: This practice was performed by special priests called augurs.
tasks.introText: Romans had various methods of seeking divine guidance.
tasks.postSolutionText: Augury was the practice of interpreting omens from the observed flight of birds. It was an important part of Roman state religion and decision-making.

tasks.question: Who is considered the first Roman Emperor?
tasks.hint: He was born as Octavian and was Julius Caesar's adopted heir.
tasks.introText: The transition from Republic to Empire was gradual and complex.
tasks.postSolutionText: Augustus, born as Octavian, became the first Roman Emperor after defeating Mark Antony and Cleopatra in 31 BCE.

tasks.question: Match the emperors with their dynasties:
tasks.hint: Each dynasty is named after its founding emperor or family.
tasks.introText: The Roman Empire was ruled by several dynasties over its history.
tasks.postSolutionText: These dynasties represent different periods of the Roman Empire, each with its own characteristics and achievements.

tasks.question: The ___ ___ was a period of relative peace and stability in the Roman Empire.
tasks.hint: This Latin phrase means 'Roman Peace'.
tasks.introText: The early Roman Empire saw a long period of relative peace and prosperity.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Pax Romana, or 'Roman Peace', lasted approximately from 27 BCE to 180 CE, marked by relative peace and stability in the empire.

tasks.question: The Roman Senate was abolished with the establishment of the Empire.
tasks.hint: Consider how Augustus and later emperors maintained a facade of republican institutions.
tasks.introText: The transition to empire involved changes in political institutions.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. The Senate continued to exist under the Empire, though with diminished power. Emperors often used it to maintain a veneer of republican tradition.

tasks.question: What was the Praetorian Guard?
tasks.hint: They were an elite unit based in Rome, with significant political influence.
tasks.introText: Security was a major concern for Roman emperors.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Praetorian Guard was the emperor's personal bodyguard. They became increasingly powerful, often playing a role in imperial politics and successions.

tasks.question: Which famous general crossed the Alps with elephants to attack Rome?
tasks.hint: This Carthaginian general led the invasion during the Second Punic War.
tasks.introText: Rome faced many external threats throughout its history.
tasks.postSolutionText: Hannibal Barca, the Carthaginian general, famously crossed the Alps with elephants in 218 BCE during the Second Punic War.

tasks.question: Match the Roman provinces with their modern-day locations:
tasks.hint: Roman provinces often correspond to modern countries or regions.
tasks.introText: The Roman Empire encompassed a vast territory across Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East.
tasks.postSolutionText: These provinces represent some of the major territories of the Roman Empire, showing its vast extent across different regions.

tasks.question: The Roman ___ was a wheeled vehicle used for various purposes, including warfare and racing.
tasks.hint: This vehicle was famously used in the Circus Maximus.
tasks.introText: Romans used various vehicles for transportation and entertainment.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Roman chariot was a key technology, used in warfare, ceremonial processions, and famously in chariot races at the Circus Maximus.

tasks.question: The Romans invented the arch in architecture.
tasks.hint: Consider earlier civilizations that used arches.
tasks.introText: The arch was a crucial element in Roman architecture.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. While Romans perfected and extensively used the arch, it was invented earlier. The Romans, however, were the first to fully exploit its potential in architecture and engineering.

tasks.question: What Roman invention was used for lifting heavy objects in construction?
tasks.hint: This device used a combination of pulleys and levers.
tasks.introText: Romans developed various machines to aid in construction.
tasks.postSolutionText: The crane was a significant Roman invention that greatly facilitated the construction of large buildings and monuments. It used a system of pulleys and levers to lift heavy objects.

tasks.question: Which of these is NOT a Roman architectural order?
tasks.hint: Three of these are Greek orders adopted by Romans.
tasks.introText: Romans adopted and adapted Greek architectural styles.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Ionic, Doric, and Corinthian orders were Greek styles adopted by Romans. The 'Roman' order is not a recognized architectural order.

tasks.question: Match the Roman buildings with their functions:

possibleAnswers.Function: Center of political and social activity

tasks.hint: Each building had a specific role in Roman public life.
tasks.introText: Roman architecture served various social, political, and religious functions.
tasks.postSolutionText: These iconic Roman buildings showcase the diversity of Roman architecture and its importance in public life.

tasks.question: Roman sculpture was known for its ___, especially in portrait busts and statues.
tasks.hint: Roman artists aimed to capture true likenesses, including flaws.
tasks.introText: Roman art had distinct characteristics that set it apart from other ancient styles.
tasks.postSolutionText: Roman sculpture, particularly portraiture, was renowned for its realism. Artists aimed to capture accurate likenesses, including imperfections, unlike the idealized forms in Greek art.

tasks.question: Mosaics were only used for floor decoration in Roman buildings.
tasks.hint: Consider all possible surfaces in a Roman building.
tasks.introText: Mosaics were a popular form of Roman art.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. While often used for floors, Roman mosaics also decorated walls and ceilings. They were used in both public buildings and private homes, depicting various scenes and patterns.

tasks.question: What type of painting was commonly used to decorate the walls of Roman houses?
tasks.hint: This technique involves painting on wet plaster.
tasks.introText: Romans had various techniques for decorating their homes.
tasks.postSolutionText: Fresco painting, done on wet plaster, was widely used in Roman wall decoration. Many examples have been preserved in places like Pompeii and Herculaneum.

tasks.question: In which year did the Western Roman Empire fall?
tasks.hint: This date marks the deposition of the last Western Roman Emperor.
tasks.introText: The fall of Rome was a gradual process, but historians often point to a specific date.
tasks.postSolutionText: 476 CE is traditionally considered the fall of the Western Roman Empire, when the last emperor, Romulus Augustulus, was deposed by Odoacer.

tasks.question: Match these factors with their roles in Rome's decline:
tasks.hint: Rome's fall was due to a combination of internal and external factors.
tasks.introText: Many factors contributed to the decline of the Roman Empire.
tasks.postSolutionText: The fall of Rome was a complex process involving multiple interconnected factors, both internal and external to the empire.

tasks.question: The Eastern Roman Empire, also known as the ___ Empire, continued for nearly 1000 years after the fall of the West.
tasks.hint: This empire was centered around Constantinople.
tasks.introText: The Eastern part of the Roman Empire had a different fate than the West.
tasks.postSolutionText: The Byzantine Empire, centered in Constantinople, continued the Roman legacy in the East until 1453 CE, nearly a millennium after the fall of the Western Empire.

tasks.question: The adoption of Christianity as the official religion contributed to the fall of Rome.
tasks.hint: Consider the timing of Christianity's adoption and Rome's fall.
tasks.introText: The role of religion in Rome's fall is a subject of historical debate.
tasks.postSolutionText: False. While some historians have argued this, Christianity became the official religion long after Rome's decline began. The Eastern Empire, which was Christian, survived for centuries longer.

tasks.question: Which 'barbarian' leader sacked Rome in 410 CE?
tasks.hint: He was the king of the Visigoths.
tasks.introText: Rome faced several invasions in its later years.
tasks.postSolutionText: Alaric, king of the Visigoths, sacked Rome in 410 CE. This event shocked the Roman world and is often seen as a key moment in the empire's decline.
